title: 108_hr2725
content: The "Railroad Track Modernization Act of 2003" may be cited as the official title. Chapter 223 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include "CAPITAL GRANTS FOR RAILROAD TRACK." The Secretary of Transportation will establish a program of capital grants for the rehabilitation, preservation, or improvement of railroad track for class II and class III railroads, including roadbed, bridges, and related structures. Grants will be provided for track used primarily for freight transportation to ensure safe and efficient operation, including handling 286,000 pound rail cars. Grants may be given directly to the railroads. The Secretary of Transportation will establish a program of capital grants for the rehabilitation, preservation, or improvement of railroad track for class II and class III railroads. Grants can be given directly to the railroads or with the approval of the railroads, to a State or local government. State transportation agencies are encouraged to assist railroad applicants in applying for and administering grants. Temporary regulations will be issued by the Secretary by December 31, 2003 to implement the program. The Secretary will issue final regulations by October 1, 2004, for a program providing 80% Federal share for track projects. Eligibility requires track ownership by class II or class III railroads. Grants must be used for rehabilitation, preservation, or improvement of railroad track. Grants under this section must be used for track capital projects promptly. Funds not obligated by the end of the third fiscal year will be returned for reallocation. Recipient railroads must provide fair arrangements for affected employees. The Secretary will ensure compliance with labor standards, including prevailing wages. The Secretary will ensure that laborers and mechanics in construction work financed by grants will be paid prevailing wages as determined by the Davis-Bacon Act. Wage rates in collective bargaining agreements under the Railway Labor Act are deemed compliant with the Davis-Bacon Act. The Secretary will conduct a study on the public benefits of light density railroad networks and report recommendations to Congress by March 31, 2005. $350,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006 for this purpose. Capital grants for railroad track are authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006.
